g.text: on coﬀee areas in an interdisciplinary approach, including local climate evaluation
to achieve a balance between temperature attenuation and production.
Coﬀee is the most consumed and popular beverage in the world after water, having
and an average of $20 billion dollars of exports per year (according to the Global
specie because it tastes better than
ments have been growing fast in coﬀee industry, mainly in producing countries such
as Brazil, Colombia, Vietnam, Ethiopia, and Indonesia.
The industry and consumers are increasingly demanding for quality and sustainabil-
ity. Nevertheless, although the global demand increases, coﬀee production may be
seriously threatened by a changing climate (
specie, due to its sensitiveness to high temperatures,
and changes of seasonal rainfall pattern (
). These conditions make coﬀee lose suitable areas (
). In Brazil, it is especially relevant because
it is the largest and most important coﬀee producer in the world, with a production
sector that generates many jobs, moves the economy, and gives opportunities to
In this context, the future of coﬀee production in climate change scenarios demands
), based on investments in public programs and regional management practices
aiming synergies between adaptation and mitigation actions (
perennial nature of coﬀee crop requires careful planning to adaptive management ac-
), and alternatives must be proposed to smallholders consid-
ering local characteristics as market demand, climate, and tradition.
The challenges of coﬀee production in a climate change context are the following: (i)
mitigation, linked to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions, and stocking of at-
mospheric carbon; and (ii) adaptation, based on the development of techniques to
erent climatic scenarios that present high frequency of
extreme events, and warmer temperatures than the current.
